awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Self-Adaptive Cyber Risk Management via  Machine to Machine Economy Supported by Blockchain and Smart Contracts  Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This project advances cybersecurity of large scale blockchain-enabled Internet of Things (IoT) systems via a novel organization of machine to machine (M2M) economy. Blockchain is a decentralized and distributed ledger. The IoT is a system of interconnected computing devices on which the emergence of 5G technology has an accelerating effect. The M2M economy is a collection of machines acting as economic agents that autonomously interact through sequences of transactions. Blockchain technology enables the registry of these transactions whose logic is articulated and coded in the form of smart contracts. These technologies have transformational potential and hold the promise of unprecedented economic growth, but they come with many vulnerabilities. This research contributes to the progress of science, advancement of prosperity and welfare, and securing the national defense through a new mechanism to enable security and cost efficient interactions on M2M platforms. The novel idea is to design market incentives such that services among machines are bought and sold based not only on their cost but also on the cyber-riskiness of the devices providing those services.

The project envisions decentralized systems that are self-adapting to cyber-risk and facilitate security and cost efficient interactions on platforms based on blockchain and IoT. The challenges are lack of: (a) real-time market design and self-optimization mechanisms; (b) scalable approaches for real-time attack identification across programs and high-level logics; (c) methods to assess M2M specific attack impact. Responding to these challenges, this project interprets the problem of creating a cyber-secure and economically efficient IoT/blockchain-based ecosystem as one of designing large-scale interconnected markets. Each of these markets has a price adjustment mechanism that may discriminate based on real-time cyber-risk. Collectively, these markets give rise to an overall emergent property of cyber-risks and economic efficiency self-adaptive optimization. Vulnerability assessment is the key to generate cyber-risk and price appropriate adjustments. This project comprehensively assesses M2M specific vulnerabilities by articulating attack graphs, hence contributing to characterizing the cyber-risk of decentralized applications for smart contract platforms. By using tools of random graph theory and percolation theory, the project provides a representative mathematical framework for understanding the cyber-risk of a IoT/blockchain-based ecosystem. Finally, as a showcase, the project applies the proposed mechanism to the use case of large-scale personalized treatment delivery.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Motivation: The broad adoption and availability of 5g technology and the consequent growth of IoT devices and their capabilities have de-facto enabled the same devices to acts as autonomous economic agents that can interact through transactions within the network. In such reality, large-scale networks of autonomous agents would transact together and autonomously engage in a financial relationships of buying and selling various services. Such IoT enabled architecture holds the promise of higher performance of networked devices that can autonomously interact to minimize adaptable rewards. However, such an interconnected system of economic agents based on IoT devices is also potentially exposed to multiple forms of cyber risk.

Project Goal: The goal of this proposal is to design a conceptual framework for secure large-scale Internet of Things (IoT) and blockchain-enabled machine-to-machine (M2M) economies by developing tools that scale efficiently to arbitrarily large IoT ecosystems, and measures for evaluation and probabilistic characterization of the IoT ecosystem cyber risk. The project's overarching hypothesis is that the proper structuring of market incentives, where services are bought and sold based not only on their cost but also on the degree of cyber riskiness of the machines providing the services, can create decentralized systems that are self-adapting with respect to cyber risk. 

Fig. 1

Foundations of cyber risk modeling. In this activity, we developed modeling approaches and mathematical techniques to study the size of a cyber-attack, which, in our modeling framework, is related to the number of vertices in a particular bond percolation cluster. Our approach involved stochastic processes that account for attack arrivals, random graphs (Figure 1: Random Graph of a Hospital IT system; Source: Chiaradonna, S., Jevtić, P., & Lanchier, N. (2023). Framework for cyber risk loss distribution of hospital infrastructure: Bond percolation on mixed random graphs approach. Risk Analysis, 43(12), 2450-2485.) that account for the dynamic nature of specific networks, and contagion processes captured via percolation theory. The contagion process accounts for various paths that contagion can take, starting from a certain point and mapping out a subgraph of a particular size. In a series of papers both published, submitted, or in preparation, we devise notation, modeling approach, and probabilistic techniques relevant to foundations of cyber risk modeling.

Generating attack vectors. We have proactively identified multiple attack vectors against M2M economies and developed automated techniques to detect vulnerabilities in smart contracts, significantly enhancing defenders' ability to anticipate potential attacks and envision future cyber risks, leading to more proactive risk models. Our developments include Linux kernel attack analysis, dynamic analysis tools for smart contracts such as fuzzing techniques and symbolic execution methods, as well as vulnerability-based risk prediction algorithms. Additionally, we have created LLM-SmartAudit, a novel framework leveraging Large Language Models to detect and analyze vulnerabilities in smart contracts with greater accuracy and efficiency than traditional tools, employing a multi-agent approach to identify complex logic vulnerabilities often overlooked by conventional methods. Our research findings and prototypes are published in academic papers and open-sourced on GitHub, contributing to the broader cybersecurity community's efforts in safeguarding M2M economies and blockchain technologies.

Modeling cyberattack framework in critical manufacturing process controlled by M2M economies. 

Our objective was to formalize new attack categories on the cyber-physical systems of a high value manufacturing systems, provide ways to deploy them, alternative ways to detect them and provide an empirical analysis for the system. To support our empirical analysis for the effectiveness of the attacks we needed to develop libraries for the efficient instantiation of discrete event models that can synchronize with the real manufacturing systems in real time (Figure 2: DTFab Framework). This project has resulted in the open DTFab library which allows users to create manufacturing test benches in the semiconductors domain for verifying a large number of possible vulnerabilities that specifically arise with the use of Digital Twins in the control loop. In particular, we developed a digital twin in the loop controller by proposing a reinforcement learning algorithm that produces state based recommendations for the tool change in the system using real time information. Our results show that the policy generated by our algorithm beats statistically the current heuristic policy that does not rely on a DT model. This allows for testing attacks (stealthy and not). We believe it is a fundamental contribution to the community to provide a modular environment to develop DTs for manufacturing systems as well as pre-made, template algorithms that use such models for control.
